answers.answer: Make sure you don't have any underlying problems like Diabetes which can cause this.  I have learned that although we brush our teeth 2-3 times a day we may not be brushing thoroughly.  You want a very soft toothbrush and brush thoroughly and not aggressively.  Always floss at night, and again gently but thoroughly.  Dry mouth does make this worse, but your's appears to be very aggressive and you may want to see your doctor to make sure there's nothing else going on.  I hope this helps and take care.

question: Please help me, somebody. I seem to have an abnormal proliferation of plaque/calculus/gunk, despite efforts at least on par with normal. I brush my teeth twice a day. I do not floss daily, but I do clean between my teeth with a professional dental scaler and StimuDents. Despite this, I have calculus and brown gunk on my teeth all the time! I can never seem to get caught up with it. I'm certainly not perfect but it seems like what I do ought to be enough to at least be able to keep up. Does tartar grow this fast in anyone else? As much as I worry about it, it seems to stay uncontrollable.I do smoke, I do suffer from dry mouth, and I did not until recently use fluoride toothpaste (used baking soda and hydrogen peroxide.) My weight and diet are good and I have no other health problems. I eat very little sugar.  I just started using Gel-Kam and Closys. Is this normal? Does calculus develop overnight?Please help me. I don't understand.
title: Excessive tartar??
